content_scrubbed:
I remember the moment I decided to go to grad school. It had been a lingering thought for several months, but one I didn't invest much time or effort into figuring out right away. I was a junior in undergrad who dual majored in English and philosophy. 

While walking with my philosophy professor one night, I realized, quickly and all of a sudden, that I HAD to go to grad school. I had learned so much, enriched my life so greatly, that I thought it would be "selfish" of me if I didn't share all that I had learned (and would continue to learn) with other students. It was a sort of existential demand. 

I don't mean to suggest that everyone has or should have an experience similar to mine. Of course not. I imagine many others have a more practical, reasoned approach to making the decision. But that[.] how I figured it out. I didn't want to do anything else. 

As far as thinking it was worth it, my experience may not relate to yours (you're in STEM, right?). I'm in the humanities, which has a crumbling job market, and I'm not in a top 25 program (but it[.] still good). The only thing encouraging possible regret is the mass amount of student loans I've accumulated. I just maxed them out and have to apply for PLUS loans. Given the bleak job prospects and the student loan that will survive my death, I don't regret it at all. I've worked several different types of jobs (blue collar, corporate life (6. 5 soul crushing years), and tattooing) and I know I wouldn't have it any other way. I love what I do and study and this is the life I want. Absolutely.

Hope this gave you some kind of insight (apologies if it[.] a ramble).
